title: Benjamin Wegner Nørregaard
text:
Benjamin Wegner Nørregaard (3 October 1861 – 24 April 1935) was a Norwegian military officer, <a href="Railway%20engineering">railway engineer</a>, <a href="adventurer">adventurer</a>, journalist, diplomat and internationally renowned <a href="war%20correspondent">war correspondent</a>. He spent several years in <a href="China">China</a> and served as Minister of Labour in the <a href="Tianjin%20Provisional%20Government">Tianjin Provisional Government</a> during the <a href="Boxer%20Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a>. He later worked as a war correspondent for the "<a href="Daily%20Mail">Daily Mail</a>" and for Scandinavian newspapers, and covered several conflicts in <a href="East%20Asia">East Asia</a> and <a href="Europe">Europe</a>. He is especially known for his books "The Great Siege", on the <a href="siege%20of%20Port%20Arthur">siege of Port Arthur</a> during the <a href="Russo-Japanese%20War">Russo-Japanese War</a>, and "War", on the <a href="Boxer%20Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a>.
Career.
Nørregaard graduated as an officer in 1881 and became a <a href="Captain%20%28OF-2%29">captain</a> in the <a href="field%20artillery">field artillery</a> in the <a href="Norwegian%20Army">Norwegian Army</a> in 1894. Described as an <a href="adventurer">adventurer</a>, he left the country in 1895 without permission of his military superiors, effectively ending his military career, and in the following years, he lived in <a href="East%20Asia">East Asia</a> during a period marked by upheavals and war. He worked as a railway engineer for the <a href="Imperial%20Chinese%20Railways">Imperial Chinese Railways</a> from 1896 to 1900. During the <a href="Boxer%20Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a> in 1900, he was employed by the <a href="Eight-Nation%20Alliance">Allies</a> as head of the Ministry of Labour in the <a href="Tianjin%20Provisional%20Government">Tianjin Provisional Government</a>, which governed the major city <a href="Tianjin">Tianjin</a> and surrounding areas, a position he held from 1900 to 1902. He was also the architect of the new, monumental government building in Tianjin.
He rose to journalistic prominence as a war correspondent of the "<a href="Daily%20Mail">Daily Mail</a>" during the <a href="Russo-Japanese%20War">Russo-Japanese War</a> (1904–05) and during the <a href="First%20Balkan%20War">First Balkan War</a> (1912–13). He witnessed the <a href="Siege%20of%20Port%20Arthur">Siege of Port Arthur</a> and published the book "The Great Siege: The Investment and Fall of Port Arthur" (<a href="Methuen%20Publishing">Methuen Publishing</a>, 1906) and the book "War" (1908) on the Boxer Rebellion, which were "written with great journalistic talent." From 1906 to 1908, he lived in <a href="St.%20Petersburg">St. Petersburg</a> as a foreign correspondent of the Norwegian newspaper "<a href="Morgenbladet">Morgenbladet</a>" and the Danish newspaper "<a href="Vort%20Land">Vort Land</a>", and gave a vivid portrayal of the revolutionary turmoil in Russia. In 1909, he relocated to Berlin as a correspondent for "Morgenbladet". In the same year, he was appointed a "secret press envoy" to Berlin and <a href="Paris">Paris</a> for the <a href="Norwegian%20Ministry%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs">Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a>, a position he held until 1911. From 1911, he was permanently employed by "<a href="Morgenbladet">Morgenbladet</a>". He also wrote for the Swedish newspaper "<a href="Dagens%20Nyheter">Dagens Nyheter</a>". During the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, he was among the leading commentators on the ongoing war in the neutral countries. In addition to writing on war and foreign policy, he was a <a href="Food%20writing">food writer</a>, and wrote humorous short stories.
He was a son of the Norwegian colonel and aide-de-camp to king Charles <a href="Hans%20Jacob%20N%C3%B8rregaard">Hans Jacob Nørregaard</a> and Sophie Wegner. His mother was a daughter of the industrialist <a href="Benjamin%20Wegner">Benjamin Wegner</a> and Henriette Seyler, of the Hamburg <a href="Berenberg-Gossler-Seyler%20banking%20dynasty">Berenberg-Gossler-Seyler banking dynasty</a>. He was a brother of the noted lawyer <a href="Harald%20N%C3%B8rregaard">Harald Nørregaard</a> and of wine merchant and consul in <a href="Tarragona">Tarragona</a> Ludvig Paul Rudolf Nørregaard. He married Wilhelmine Sissenère in 1898. She was formerly married to the Norwegian cabinet minister and Director-General of the <a href="Norwegian%20State%20Railways%20%281883%E2%80%931996%29">Norwegian State Railways</a> <a href="Hans%20Hein%20Theodor%20Nysom">Hans Nysom</a>. He had no children.
He is mentioned as a military and foreign policy commentator in "<a href="Morgenbladet">Morgenbladet</a>" during the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> in the novel "<a href="Lillelord">Lillelord</a>" by <a href="Johan%20Borgen">Johan Borgen</a>.
